repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem:
`vim.system` is recommended over `vim.fn.system`.

Solution:
Follow own recommendation.

---

Off-topic, but there are a lot of `vim.fn.executable` / `vim.fn.exepath` calls here and there, which [seem to be slow](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/31506). I think most of them can just run the command and see if it fails? (ofc not an option when you want to differentiate between executable not installed and 'this particular command fails', reliably. Or is `code == 127` reliable enough?)

Edit: nvm, vim.system throws an error if the command is not available, so you have to work with pcall's etc. Not ideal.

comment_data.body: vim.fn.system combines stdout and stderr. we probably need to do that here.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,8 +1,17 @@
 local M = {}
 local health = require('vim.health')
 
-local shell_error = function()
-  return vim.v.shell_error ~= 0
+---Run a system command and return without error and its stdout.
+---@param cmd string|string[]
+---@return boolean
+---@return string
+local function system(cmd)
+  if type(cmd) == 'string' then
+    cmd = vim.split(cmd, ' ')
+  end
+  local result = vim.system(cmd, { text = true }):wait()
+  -- NOTE: `or ''` to please the type checker
+  return result.code == 0, vim.trim(result.stdout or '')

comment_data.body: can we update the callers instead so they always pass a list ?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -4,8 +4,16 @@ local iswin = vim.fn.has('win32') == 1
 local M = {}
 
 local function cmd_ok(cmd)
-  local out = vim.fn.system(cmd)
-  return vim.v.shell_error == 0, out
+  if type(cmd) == 'string' then

comment_data.body: Sure! I thought it would be convenient since there's a lot of `cmd_ok(vim.split('tmux config xyz', ' '))` in the file.
comment_data.diff_hunk:

-  local out = vim.fn.system(cmd)
-  return vim.v.shell_error == 0, out
+  if type(cmd) == 'string' then

comment_data.body: I'm not sure why, the commands do seem to expect stdout, not stderr perse. If you're talking about the note, it's to fix 'wrong' typing. I can also change it to `--[[@as string]]` if that's better.

depends on the command. i guess we can ignore this for now.

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -302,15 +311,15 @@ local function check_tmux()
   -- check default-terminal and $TERM
   health.info('$TERM: ' .. vim.env.TERM)
   local cmd = 'tmux show-option -qvg default-terminal'

comment_data.body: will need to join `cmd` here, if we change it to a list
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -302,15 +311,15 @@ local function check_tmux()
   -- check default-terminal and $TERM
   health.info('$TERM: ' .. vim.env.TERM)
   local cmd = 'tmux show-option -qvg default-terminal'
-  local out = vim.fn.system(vim.fn.split(cmd))
+  local ok, out = system(cmd)
   local tmux_default_term = vim.fn.substitute(out, [[\v(\s|\r|\n)]], '', 'g')
   if tmux_default_term == '' then
     cmd = 'tmux show-option -qvgs default-terminal'
-    out = vim.fn.system(vim.fn.split(cmd))
+    ok, out = system(cmd)
     tmux_default_term = vim.fn.substitute(out, [[\v(\s|\r|\n)]], '', 'g')
   end
 
-  if shell_error() then
+  if not ok then
     health.error('command failed: ' .. cmd .. '\n' .. out)

-    local out = vim.fn.system(vim.fn.split(cmd))
+    local ok, out = system(vim.split(cmd, ' '))

comment_data.body: why remove this? it was designed to handle `string[]` list commands. it does more than just table.concat()

--- Attempts to construct a shell command from an args list.
--- Only for display, to help users debug a failed command.
---- @param cmd string|string[]
-local function shellify(cmd)
-  if type(cmd) ~= 'table' then
-    return cmd

comment_data.body: cli_version() returns multiple args, what does `tostring()` print here?

-    local tmux_version = string.match(vim.fn.system('tmux -V'), '%d+%.%d+')

comment_data.body: 👍🏼. The problem is not valid though: `result.stdout` is only nil when `vim.system` receives `stdout = function() end` in opts, which it is not. I'm not sure if that type definition can be improved (i.e. if luals handles those more fine-grained type annotations?)
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: I think that was originally so because later on the full cmd is printed on error, thus it's either `split()` or `table.concat`. It's probably better to define as a list and then use `table.concat` for error output, as error output is expected less.

comment_data.body: this isn't going to work. multi-return can't be indexed. need to either surround with `({ ... })` or save to a local var.

-      'Failed to run: ' .. latest_gem_cmd,
+      'Failed to run: ' .. table.concat(latest_gem_cmd, ' '),

comment_regular_data.body:
> Edit: nvm, vim.system throws an error if the command is not available, so you have to work with pcall's etc. Not ideal.

For what it's worth, I raised this as a concern once. My comment is linked below, and there's discussion in the following thread. (In one of my comments I used [nearly identical language about this being "not ideal."](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/11311#issuecomment-2329301458)) You have to unminimize some of the comments to read them.

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/11311#issuecomment-2329244669

Thanks! I agree that (from a `vim.system` user perspective) it's weird that there's a difference between a failed command and a command which does not exist. 

I would be really interested to see a comparison of speeds between `pcall(vim.system({ cmd }):wait())` and `vim.fn.executable(cmd) == 1`.

In 5b8bc3615163e6de87f8804f0bf1458016b3bbf8 I've replaced the custom `system()` which used functionos like `vim.fn.jobstart` and friends with `vim.system()`. However I'm not feeling 100% confident the new implementation matches the new behaviour. The checkhealth output seems fine. Anyone that can review?
Hm `vim.system` seems to be not available when building Nvim for lintcommit. Any suggestions on how to fix?

> `vim.system` seems to be not available when building Nvim for lintcommit

try changing this `-u NONE` to `--clean` , or `-u NORC` : https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4f141dca8c888d62b332f31fd51fa3e9b2e6cb89/CMakeLists.txt#L280
we are close to finishing this, but please avoid making more unrelated changes so we can finish this without more rounds of review

repo.name: neovim

title: refactor(lua): vim.fn.system to vim.system
